author: Todd Fitzgerald
title: Why is there a nasty smell on the M60 by Stockport?
text:
Why is there a nasty smell on the M60 by Stockport? This is what's causing the pong... Share Get daily     
Ever been driving along the M60 through Stockport and wondered what the horrendous smell is? 
Well, wonder no more...this is what’s causing the pong. 
Behind the trees lining the motorway, sits the Stockport Waste Treatment Works. The vast sewerage plant is largely hidden from view, but the stench it creates sweeps across the motorway, particularly if it’s picked up in a southerly wind. 
The smell is pretty strong on a hot summer’s day, so be sure to wind your windows up. Not that it will make much difference. 
Obnoxious smells from the plant have blighted the town for over 60 years. Read More GMP bosses apologise after blind man was tasered when his walking stick was mistaken for a gun 
But residents from outside the area are often clueless as to what the smell is. 
The United Utilities-owned site, off Heathside Park Road in Cheadle Heath, sits beside the M60 just before junction 3 for Cheadle on the anticlockwise stretch, after the Stockport Pyramid. 
To the north, the site is bounded by the River Mersey. 
To the south of the M60, are hundreds of houses. Residents who have to put up with the smell all-year-round, but things were a lot worse a decade ago. 
Back in 2005, the smell got so bad, the council nearly took United Utilities to court for causing a public nuisance. 
Soaring temperatures, restrictions on spreading slurry during the foot and mouth crisis and the breakdown of important machinery caused an almighty whiff. 
Sewerage could not be sent out to farms as normal and had to be stored on site, creating an eye-watering odour. Read More Waitrose recalls popular frozen fish because of possible health risk 
Scores of residents from Cheadle Heath, Shaw Heath, Edgeley and even across the river in Heaton Mersey said the smell was so unbearable they couldn’t in their gardens or open windows. 
Eventually, plant bosses ploughed more than £9m into tackling the problem - and it isn’t so bad nowadays. 
During the 1970s, Cheadle Heath home owners won a five per cent rates reduction to sweeten up the bad smell. Like us on Facebook
